messages.text:
Hi Everyone. I use `nvim` with the Julia LSP server (julials). Today, after not having been using it for a while, I noticed it stopped working. Changes I've made recently include:
• Updating `nvim`  (I have NVIM v0.5.0-dev+965-gd0668b36a installed).
• Removed the `diagnostic-nvim` plugin since it is deprecated and its features have been moved to nvim core. I followed this <https://github.com/nvim-lua/diagnostic-nvim/issues/73|migration guide> 
• Switched to Julia 1.5.3
This is the content of `lsp.log` :

elements.text: Hi Everyone. I use

Removed the
diagnostic-nvim
plugin since it is deprecated and its features have been moved to nvim core. I followed this
migration guide
Switched to Julia 1.5.3

messages.text:
Hail and well met fellow traveler! :crossed_swords: Welcome to <#CA8TYH0LU|vim> <@U01AJUF2GEP> - sit by the :fire: and chat a while :beers: .

Regarding Julia LSP, I used it with Neovim 5 and found it extremely buggy. Decided not to engage with it too much as the autocompletion was not great and found it slowed down my workflow. It has great potential, but not something I can invest in right now.

messages.text:
re-posting from zulip:

I have some admittedly idiosyncratic preferences for my indentations.  In particular, I want all closing delimiters to occur at the start of new lines,  unless they enclose function arguments.

So, for example, currently if I write a closing delimiter on a new line I get, e.g.
```julia
Dict(:a=>1,
     :b=>2,
    )```
What I *want* is
```julia
Dict(:a=>1,
     :b=>2,
)```
For functions, what I get is
```julia
function f(x=1;
        kwarg1=2
    )
end```
but what I *want* is
```julia
function f(x=1;
           kwarg1=2
          )
end```
Anyone know what I can set to achieve this?  I figure the first one is probably easy

messages.text:
<@UUS6GL8BH>
1. Regarding tmux + kak, its better to just install the kitty terminal... Heck, its the most awesome terminal I've ever used. Then you won't need tmux at all.
2. The momentum in kak, (as awesome as the software itself is) is kinda... slow or dead... I think it's because there're waaaay less people working on kak and kak-lsp. The fixes come in 2-4 years... which means we've to probably implement the stuff we want ourselves.
3. Listing the stuff - 1. A better implementation for the lsp-hover in kak-lsp and 2. Figuring if the problem in unicode auto-complete lies within kakoune or kak-lsp, and then fixing it.

elements.text: Regarding tmux + kak, its better to just install the kitty terminal... Heck, its the most awesome terminal I've ever used. Then you won't need tmux at all.

The momentum in kak, (as awesome as the software itself is) is kinda... slow or dead... I think it's because there're waaaay less people working on kak and kak-lsp. The fixes come in 2-4 years... which means we've to probably implement the stuff we want ourselves.
Listing the stuff - 1. A better implementation for the lsp-hover in kak-lsp and 2. Figuring if the problem in unicode auto-complete lies within kakoune or kak-lsp, and then fixing it.

messages.text: If the above problems are fixed, I think kakoune is good enough to deserve a mention in <http://julialang.org|julialang.org>:slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: If the above problems are fixed, I think kakoune is good enough to deserve a mention in
julialang.org

messages.text:
So... <@UUS6GL8BH> and other users of Kakoune

kakoune doesn't provide auto-indent for julia
The lsp just provides a format option, not auto-indent

I've submitted a PR to kakoune, to implement auto-indent features for julia, but before it gets merged and released.... <https://github.com/mawww/kakoune/pull/4051>
Feel free to copy and paste this to your julia.kak file (`/usr/share/kak/rc/filetype/julia.kak` in linux)
<https://raw.githubusercontent.com/clad26/kakoune/patch-1/rc/filetype/julia.kak>

elements.text: So...

and other users of Kakoune

kakoune doesn't provide auto-indent for julia
The lsp just provides a format option, not auto-indent

I've submitted a PR to kakoune, to implement auto-indent features for julia, but before it gets merged and released....
Feel free to copy and paste this to your julia.kak file (
/usr/share/kak/rc/filetype/julia.kak
in linux)

messages.text:
I'm saying this because it doesn't support vimL & can't use existing vim plugins directly? (unlike, e.g neovim) And I can't use Kakoune stuff in vim.

I don't care if it's also a "modal editor" and has "vim-like key binding" out of the box, it's not vim (compatible)

messages.text:
I feel a bit silly asking this, but I'm having a lot of trouble getting kakoune to work. I did all the things in the LanguageServer.jl tutorial but I have no idea how the plugin system is supposed to work. This is the error:
```*** This is the debug buffer, where debug info will be written ***
/home/peterj/.config/kak/kakrc:no such command: 'plug'
/usr/share/kak/kakrc:29:1: 'evaluate-commands' 116:1: 'source' no such command: 'plug'
error while parsing kakrc:
    1:1: 'source' 29:1: 'evaluate-commands' 116:1: 'source' no such command: 'plug'```

messages.text: Not Julia related, but hopefully someone can help: has anyone encountered an issue where vim won't 'remember' the correct word boundaries? I have `set nocompatible` in my `.vimrc`, and for a while things work right, but then vim seems to revert the the vi style word movements where only whitespace denotes a new word. I can fix it by executing `:set nocompatible`, but vim isn't actually forgetting that setting because `:set nocompatible?` still reports `nocompatible` . Eventually it reverts to the vi behavior again, and I have to `:set nocompatible` again. Anyone know what's  up?

:set nocompatible?
still reports
nocompatible
. Eventually it reverts to the vi behavior again, and I have to
:set nocompatible
again. Anyone know what's  up?

messages.text: I use a tmux + nvim setup to write Julia code. I open nvim in a left tmux pane, and a Julia REPL on a right pane. The REPL has a feature that lets you open a file referenced in a Stacktrace by typing the number, e.g. [1], followed by Ctrl-q. This, however, opens the file in a new vim instance in the same pane as the REPL (the right pane). Does anybody know how to open the file in the left pane where an instance of vim is already running?

elements.text: I use a tmux + nvim setup to write Julia code. I open nvim in a left tmux pane, and a Julia REPL on a right pane. The REPL has a feature that lets you open a file referenced in a Stacktrace by typing the number, e.g. [1], followed by Ctrl-q. This, however, opens the file in a new vim instance in the same pane as the REPL (the right pane). Does anybody know how to open the file in the left pane where an instance of vim is already running?

messages.text: You would need to figure out the correct command line invocation to do the opening and then add a callback to <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/blob/909c7f3505ef4fe7c7aec83ac58af18eb5536f1b/stdlib/InteractiveUtils/src/editless.jl#L7-L15> that executes this.

elements.text: You would need to figure out the correct command line invocation to do the opening and then add a callback to
that executes this.

messages.text: I'm currently using deoplete for autocomplete, and it interferes a little with latex-to-unicode. It's usually not a problem, because my latex-to-unicode completes automatically whenever a character not in a latex command comes up like a space or delimiter, but once in a while I find myself at the end of the line and wanting to use tab. I typically have to press tab a few times to get it to work. Anyone encounter this and solve it?

messages.text:
hey guys, I have kind of an idiosynchratic annoyance:
`julia-vim` now has highlighting of functions, but regardless of how one sets the color this makes data types, `!` characters and module names in function declarations the same color.  I don't really like this, I particularly want types to have type colors and modules not to have the smae color as functions.  Is there any way of either customizing this, or restoring the original behavior on latest commits?

elements.text: hey guys, I have kind of an idiosynchratic annoyance:
julia-vim
now has highlighting of functions, but regardless of how one sets the color this makes data types,

characters and module names in function declarations the same color.  I don't really like this, I particularly want types to have type colors and modules not to have the smae color as functions.  Is there any way of either customizing this, or restoring the original behavior on latest commits?

messages.text:
even with minimal configuration:
```inoremap <expr> <tab> pumvisible() ? "\<C-n>" : "\<tab>"
inoremap <expr> <S-tab> pumvisible() ? "\<C-p>" : "\<S-Tab>"
set completeopt=menuone,noinsert,noselect
set shortmess+=c
let g:completion_enable_snippet = 'UltiSnips'
let g:completion_enable_auto_popup = 1
lua require'nvim_lsp'.sumneko_lua.setup{on_attach=require'completion'.on_attach}
au Filetype lua setl omnifunc=v:lua.vim.lsp.omnifunc```

messages.text:
I'm back on the saga of trying to get latex-to-unicode tab completion to work reliably with all completion sources.  In particular someone told me about [nvim-compe](<https://github.com/hrsh7th/nvim-compe>) which so far is my favorite completion engine but it still suffers from this problem.
As a temporary work around I am doing
```inoremap <silent><expr> <tab> pumvisible() ? "\<C-n>\<C-x>\<C-u>" : "\<tab>"```
which mostly works by forcing tab completion to *always* do latex completion no matter what, but it does have one nasty side effect of ruining selection within the pop up box

elements.text: I'm back on the saga of trying to get latex-to-unicode tab completion to work reliably with all completion sources.  In particular someone told me about [nvim-compe](

) which so far is my favorite completion engine but it still suffers from this problem.
As a temporary work around I am doing
inoremap <silent><expr> <tab> pumvisible() ? "\<C-n>\<C-x>\<C-u>" : "\<tab>"
which mostly works by forcing tab completion to
always
do latex completion no matter what, but it does have one nasty side effect of ruining selection within the pop up box

messages.text: a more permanent solution might be to add latex-to-unicode to `nvim-compe`, which it provides an interface to do, but it'll take me a while to figure out exactly how to do that well

elements.text: a more permanent solution might be to add latex-to-unicode to
nvim-compe
, which it provides an interface to do, but it'll take me a while to figure out exactly how to do that well

messages.text:
Hello all.  After some frustration with auto-complete options available in `nvim` and many of them not playing nicely with latex-to-unicode, I have implemented [a latex source](<https://gitlab.com/ExpandingMan/compe-latex>) for the [`nvim-compe`](<https://github.com/hrsh7th/nvim-compe>) auto-completion plugin.  The advantage of this is that it allows you to use `compe` with any possible latex completion appearing in the popup.

There's still at least one major loose edge: I cannot yet find an elegant way of getting `compe` to enter latex as you type, so right now I am *also* using the LaTeX-to-unicode from `julia-vim`.  As far as I can tell there is no issue with using both.

compe

with any possible latex completion appearing in the popup.

There's still at least one major loose edge: I cannot yet find an elegant way of getting
compe

also
using the LaTeX-to-unicode from
julia-vim
.  As far as I can tell there is no issue with using both.

messages.text: After much misery, I have finally, *finally* arrived at an nvim configuration that uses Julia LSP that isn't total shit and is actually usable.  If anyone is interested in my setup, you can see it [here](<https://gitlab.com/ExpandingMan/dotfiles/-/blob/master/home/.config/nvim/init.vim>)
